page.title: 20LOCAL HISTORY-HOUSES
page.content: THE ABBEY.In spite of its name this house was never a monastery.The core is mediaeval and its irregular plan would suggest that an existing structure of some size determined the character of the late 16th.century remodelling.The house originally (before the Reformation) possessed a chapel dedicated in honour of the Holy Ghost and it is probable that the shell of this exists in the present south range of buildings.The buttresses are certainly mediaeval and there are indications of a large window in the east gable.The drawing room has handsome early 17th.century panelling and there are several paintings of Oliver Cromwell,from whom the present owner of the house is descended.The house had been used as a farmstead and was restored by Claude Neville who bought it in 1902.
